0.sent: Noshin' at the Tupelo Honey Cafe | Plus, how to get great service in busy restaurants 23 Mar.

1.sent: , 2010 By the time I got to Asheville, I was nearing the end of my journey and the bottom of my wallet.

2.sent: The last thing on my mind was spending money: it was beautiful outside, and there were free things to do everywhere.

4.sent: When I'd posted on Facebook that I was coming to town, no fewer than three people told me I just had to visit the Tupelo Honey Cafe .

5.sent: So I checked their website, and instantly fell in love: "Tupelo Honey Caf√© opened in downtown Asheville in 2000, an early pioneer in the farm to fork movement and an active advocate for the independent restaurant landscape that pervades the city.

6.sent: Our food is fresh, made from scratch, sassy and scrumptious.

7.sent: Our cuisine salutes our love of Southern traditions at the table, but like the good people of Asheville, marches to its own drum.

8.sent: The result is a unique riff on Southern favorites."

9.sent: tupelohoneycafe.com I was convinced but I wasn't alone.

10.sent: On a sunny Sunday afternoon, the waiting list was an hour long.

11.sent: After hemming and hawing and assessing my food stash (contents: 10 saltines), I decided to go for it anyway.

12.sent: By the time I finally got a seat at the counter, I was starved.

13.sent: It took me about thirty seconds to pick out the Charleston Chicken Sandwich: "grilled marinated free-range chicken breast on sourdough with melted havarti, romaine lettuce and cranberry mayonnaise".

18.sent: While I waited for the food, I checked out the back of the store where Tupelo Honey Cafe hawks their homestyle wares: preserves, pickles, salsa, honey, t-shirts, aprons and all sorts of mini-advertisements for the restaurant.

19.sent: I've visited plenty of farm-to-fork restaurants, and this one may be the best I've seen at self-marketing.

20.sent: There's nothing wrong with it: the food in those jars is probably delicious, though I question whether the $10 tupelo honey had to come from Florida or if it's produced locally.

21.sent: Either way, it's nice to see a restaurant built on ethics that also happens to be incredibly busy.

22.sent: Some of that is surely due to good marketing, but the real reason for its popularity is this: That sandwich was so good, I found myself eating slower and slower with each bite to savor it more completely.

23.sent: The potatoes were light and un-greasy; the flavors were perfectly balanced; the chicken was juicy and rich; and let's be honest here, I'm always happier eating dead animals when I know they've lived a good life.

24.sent: I found myself silently thanking the chicken for its delicious contribution.

27.sent: I stopped eating halfway through, not because I was full.

28.sent: I stopped so I could take the rest home and taste it again later.

29.sent: On another topic, I made a discovery there in the Tupelo Honey Cafe, one which I'd like to share with you now.

30.sent: If you're going to a busy restaurant and want great service, bring a camera.

31.sent: Take a few photos of the menu, the kitchen, the food.

32.sent: No sooner had I taken the above photo, when a server (not even my server) appeared at my elbow.

33.sent: Later when I stopped eating and lifted my napkin from my lap, it took approximately three seconds for someone to take my food away to be boxed up.

34.sent: Now, I'm not saying the service before my camera-flash was bad, because it was awesome.

35.sent: But wow, it sure improved once I appeared to be some sort of food critic or travel writer.

36.sent: Which, it just so happens, I am.

37.sent: But even if you're not, try this out sometime.

38.sent: I can't guarantee it'll work, but I personally will do it againand probably back it up with a stellar review, just like the one I've given the Tupelo Honey Cafe.

41.sent: I could talk about Asheville for weeks, but it's time to move on.

42.sent: Next stop: sunny Tennessee, where I get down on The Farm.
